_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The six senses and their relationship to: The eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
The ear is not the fetter of sounds, nor are sounds the fetter of the ear.
The nose is not the fetter of smells, nor are smells the fetter of the nose.
The tongue is not the fetter of tastes, nor are tastes the fetter of the tongue.
The body is not the fetter of sensations, nor are sensations the fetter of the body.
The mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
The Buddha's senses and his freedom from: The Buddha has an eye with which he sees a sight. But he has no desire and greed, for his mind is well freed.
The Buddha has an ear, nose, and tongue with which he senses sounds, smells, and tastes. But he has no desire and greed, for his mind is well freed.
The Buddha has a body with which he senses touch. But he has no desire and greed, for his mind is well freed.
The Buddha has a mind with which he knows thoughts. But he has no desire and greed, for his mind is well freed.
